Award.AwardTitle: RET Site for Structured Organic Particulates

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a three year standard award to support a Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) in Engineering and Computer Science Site program at New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) entitled, "RET Site for Structured Organic Particulates", under the direction of Dr. John D. Carpinelli and Dr. Rajesh N. Dave. This proposal seeks funding to build upon the current RET Site for Structured Organic Particulates program at NJIT, in conjunction with the NSF-sponsored Engineering Research Center (ERC) on Structured Organic Particulates (C-SOPS). A total of 36 teachers, twelve high school teachers per year for three years, will engage in a six-week research program under the guidance of faculty supervisors, with follow-up programs during each school year. Participants will be high school science and technology teachers from school districts in northern and central New Jersey, with an emphasis on teachers from districts that serve large numbers of students from underrepresented populations in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). NJIT, through its Center for Pre-College Programs (CPCP), is very actively engaged with the K-12 community in New Jersey, and works with urban districts and their teachers that serve the targeted student population. CPCP works with dozens of teachers every year through various programs; its work has an immediate impact on thousands of students each year, with the vast majority from underrepresented populations.

The proposed program stems from cutting-edge C-SOPS research projects dealing with topics in pharmaceutical materials structure, function, performance, and processing, geared towards a unifying goal of improving pharmaceutical products. The fundamental knowledge from research that leads to improved design, manufacturing and quality of pharmaceutical products, will help high school teachers better understand the role of engineers and develop curriculum materials that will help their students better appreciate science and engineering. The program trains teachers in inquiry-based research, and in concepts of product design and engineering through examples from pharmaceutical engineering.

The broader impacts of this proposal are multifaceted. The RET program will significantly impact a large number of underrepresented minority students from the selected urban school districts, several of which have a large number of African-American and/or Hispanic students. Based on the results of a prior RET program at NJIT, it is anticipated that this number will be in the thousands during the course of the program, and many times more after the program ends as teachers continue to use and build upon the materials they develop through this program. As participating teachers bring their experiences and educational materials into their own classrooms, this program will ultimately reach thousands of students, and will contribute towards development of a well-trained, diverse workforce in this area of national importance. Modules will be placed in several on-line repositories available at the disposal of the C-SOPS ERC, making them accessible to scores of other educators across the country, and will be easily adaptable to meet the incoming common core standards, thus facilitating their use on a national scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this NSF funded program, we have provided a high-quality research opportunity for 38 high school teachers of science, engineering, and technology (STEM) in the general area of pharmaceutical product development. Their research involved understanding of how to create or manipulate drug and other particles or powders that go into drug products such as tablets, capsules, granules, and orally dispersing films, with an objective of reducing manufacturing cost, improving product quality, and most importantly, enhancing therapeutic value for patients from increased patient comfort to compliance. Such diverse and rich research experience from an industry that is vital to not just US economy but health and wellbeing of US population was made available through partnership with an existing NSF funded Engineering Research Center for Structured Organic Particulates (ERC-SOPS) at NJIT. 

Majority of faculty and graduate students were recruited from ERC-SOPS to provide projects that were carefully selected from ongoing research, inter-connected via technology driven test beds. This practice enabled discovery-based experiences in scientific research from which they can develop basic knowledge and skills in the area of pharmaceutical manufacturing that they can incorporate into their teaching practices. For each summer, the cohort of RETs and their companion high-school students, funded from ACS- SEED grants, were provided an overview of pharmaceutical manufacturing and ERC-SOPS research. This enabled understanding of where their individual project fits into the big picture and how their output from six weeks is designed to have an impact on the Center. Naturally, contributions from several RET participants have been included in high-quality journal papers with them as coauthors. 

Teachers were recruited from nearby high schools, many of which are from urban school districts with a large number of African-American and/or Hispanic students. They were mentored by doctoral students or postdoctoral researchers who provided them training on all aspects of research, including safety, data collection and analysis, and report generation.  In parallel, our partner, Center for Pre-College Programs (CPCP), provided a comprehensive professional development program, which included several workshops to help them develop age-appropriate modules and lessons and implement in their classrooms during the academic year. For each cohort, teachers were invited back for a one day workshop in December to report back on the use of their instructional modules. 
RET participants, mostly two in each project, worked together on innovative research concerning three general areas of research. First group involved projects that examined how pharmaceutical drugs that are practically insoluble in water, often compared to brick dust, can be made available in blood-stream so that their effectiveness is enhanced. That requires enhancing their solubility/dissolution rate in simulated gastric fluids. They learnt about the approaches based on particle size reduction, and the one changed the structure of drug from crystalline to amorphous. Second group of projects addressed challenges involved with manufacturing of powder based materials used in tablets. Teachers understood how powdered sugar poses handling challenges in contrast to granulated version and how such issues are faced on a daily basis in pharmaceutical manufacturing. They worked on simple yet esoteric solutions such as layering inert nano-sized particles onto individual fine drug powders to make them flow and handle better. Teachers examined if doing so helped reduce number of manufacturing steps and improved process reliability/product performance. Third group addressed ease of dosage administration, or patient compliance, which is a number one problem that affects disease management, particularly for pediatric and geriatric populations. In several projects, teachers formed thin drug loaded polymeric films that can dissolve quickly in mouth, eliminating the need to swallow tablets. Another project provided an engineering solution to very bitter taste of drugs to achieve taste masking. 

Such research was skillfully translated by the RETs into classroom through simplified modules. Examples include: Introduction to Scientific and Engineering Practices: Uncovering Ways to Increase Bioavailability of Drugs; Concentration of Solution: Molarity, Rate of Reaction, Disintegration of Alka Seltzer; Using Systems Engineering to Model Mixing and Coating Processes; The Chemistry and Manufacture of Chocolate and other Confectionaries; and, What is Nanoscience? 

Overall, the program had a major impact on participants. For 38 RETs, this was a unique experience that rejuvenated them to bring STEM into their classrooms with renewed enthusiasm to naturally motivate their dozens of students to pursue STEM careers. For a dozen high school students, this invaluable opportunity enabled them to compete in local and national science and technology competitions and win top prizes and enter STEM programs at college of their choice. For 26 graduate student and postdoc mentors, this was an experience in being a mentor instead of mentee and to enable productivity from their RET participants who came with significantly more work experience yet had to be trained. To all faculty and CPCP staff, this was an opportunity to work with RETs and make progress towards enhancing young generation’s appreciation for STEM careers.
